Hello javainsel,


Am Montag, 7. April 2003 15:08 schrieb javainsel:
> We use a ERP framework which sits on top of EJB.
>
> Does the framework has to provide mock objects for JUnit tests?
>
> Is it possible to use Mock objects when using a ERP framework?
>
> And which Mock objects to use? There seem to be many solutions.
First: I take this post as a confession that in the previous threads about TDD
vs. DBC you really didn't know what you were talking of, because if you were,
you wouldn't ask such questions but instead respond to my posts on these
threads to continue argueing for DBC. The reason for that is not so obvious
to me. I think positive, so I don't think you're a troll, I think it was your
way to find out how DBC and TDD interact - just say something you're not
really convinced of yourself but hold that view to see what arguments are
against it. Please, next time just ask for these arguments instead of
behaving like a time sink.


Basically, mock objects are a certain sub group of dummy objects.
The whole field of dummy objects can be classified into three kinds:
1. Stub objects which replace the real objects but don't provide all
funcionality.
2. Dummy objects which just replace the real objects.
3. Mock objects which are dummy objects or stub objects
(This helpful classification is taken from "Unit Tests mit Java" by Johannes
Link, a really good German book about Unit Testing for TDD in Java using
JUnit and some extensions and tools)


Take java.sql.ResultSet as an example.
The real object would be an implementation of ResultSet provided by a JDBC
Driver.
A Stub would be a ResultSet implementation that does not provide all features
of ResultSets.
A Dummy would be a ResultSet implementation that provides all features of
ResultSets but replaces the ResultSet of a JDBC driver within the test
because it is more convenient to test a class using a ResultSet without a
real database connection.
A Mock would be a Stub or more a Dummy which provides additional features like
generating statistics about the usage of the ResultSet, which could be logged
to a Logger (file, network or whatsoever) when the .close() or .finalize()
method is invoked, and that way could tell wether
a) All rows of the ResultSet were iterated over
b) All columns of the ResultSet were read
c) The ResultSet was correctly closed or closing was omitted

While a Dummy would behave somewhat normal, since it's task is to just replace
the real object, a Mock object could also influence the test. The Mock
ResultSet e.g. could be instructed to throw an SQLException on the third
invocation of next() to verify wether the CUT/OUT correctly deals with
exceptions.


Now to your questions:
> Does the framework has to provide mock objects for JUnit tests?
No, it's not required that the framework provides the mock objects. But it
would be helpful.
Today, most frameworks do not provide Dummies or Mocks. Some frameworks
provide stubs, like "javax.swing.table.AbstractTableModel" for
"javax.swing.table.TableModel".

> Is it possible to use Mock objects when using a ERP framework?
That depends on wether the framework deserves the name framework or not.
A real framework consists of two parts: The API/SPI and the implementation. If
the framework is a real framework, you could simply implement the API/SPI
yourself to create mock objects and replace the implementation.

But your questions do not provide the information *where* and *why* you want
to use Mock objects. So you program using the ERP API yourself? Or is it just
a code generation tool like Versata?

Providing complete mock objects can be really elaborate. In most cases, you
don't provide full featured mock objects based on dummies, but mock objects
based on stubs providing all required features.
